duck: Supposition theory was a branch of medieval logic that was probably aimed at giving accounts of issues similar to modern accounts of reference, plurality, tense, and modality, within an Aristotelian context.
Philosophers such as John Buridan, William of Ockham, William of Sherwood, Walter Burley, and Peter of Spain were key in developing it.

wiki.text:
'Supposition theory' was a branch of medieval logic that was probably aimed at
giving accounts of issues similar to modern accounts of reference, plurality,
tense, and modality, within an Aristotelian context. Philosophers such as John
Buridan, William of Ockham, William of Sherwood, Walter Burley, and Peter of
Spain were its principal developers. By the 14th century it seems to have
drifted into at least two fairly distinct theories, the theory of "supposition
proper" which included an "ampliation" and is much like a theory of reference,
and the theory of "modes of supposition" whose intended function is not clear.
wiki.title: Supposition%20theory
